thoughts.content: The user asks if zero Lyapunov exponent covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLVs) are orthogonal. Typically, CLVs reflect the system's dynamics and are not orthogonal. CLVs are covariant with the system's flow, forming an invariant subspace decomposition. While Gram-Schmidt vectors are orthonormal, CLVs are not. Zero Lyapunov exponent covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLVs) are not generally orthogonal. They belong to an invariant subspace, and while you can choose an orthonormal basis within the subspace, CLVs themselves may not be orthogonal. In certain cases, such as symmetries or multiple zero exponents, CLVs may still satisfy specific orthogonality properties, like symplectic orthogonality. However, they are typically covariant, not orthonormal. So, no, zero LE CLVs do not tend to be orthogonal, but an orthogonal basis can be chosen if desired.

In short: **no – covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLVs) that belong to zero Lyapunov exponents are _not_ generally orthogonal to one another (nor to the other CLVs).**

---

### Why orthogonality is not expected

| Concept | Gram–Schmidt (GS) “Lyapunov vectors” | Covariant Lyapunov vectors |
|---------|--------------------------------------|-----------------------------|
| How they’re constructed | Recursively orthonormalised (QR) | Intersection of forward & backward Oseledec sub-spaces |
| Main property | Mutually orthonormal at every instant | Covariant with the linearised flow: \(DF^{t}\,v_{i}(t)=\mathrm e^{\lambda_i t}\,v_{i}(t+t)\) |
| What is _sacrificed_ | Covariance (vectors shear/rotate when evolved) | Orthogonality (angles can be arbitrary) |

Because the CLVs are chosen so that each one transforms into itself under the tangent flow (up to an overall exponential factor), **nothing in their definition imposes Euclidean orthogonality**.  The zero-exponent vectors simply form an invariant _neutral_ sub-space that is tangent to continuous symmetries (time-translation, gauge, momentum conservation, …); inside that sub-space the algorithm returns _some_ basis, but not an orthonormal one.

---

### Special structures that _can_ introduce orthogonality (but only accidentally)

* **Simple, one-dimensional neutral sub-space** – e.g. the flow direction in an ODE.  There is only one vector, so orthogonality is moot.
* **Degenerate exponents** – if there are \(k\) identical zero exponents, any orthogonal \(k\times k\) rotation of the CLVs will also be a valid set of CLVs.  You may _choose_ an orthonormal basis, but the standard algorithms (Ginelli et al. 2007; Wolfe & Samelson 2007) select one that is almost never orthogonal.
* **Symplectic/Hamiltonian systems** – the full set of CLVs comes in symplectic pairs that satisfy a _skew-_ orthogonality with their **adjoint** CLVs, not ordinary Euclidean orthogonality.

---

### Practical consequences

* When you need orthogonal neutral directions (e.g. to study a quotient dynamics on a symmetry-reduced manifold), you must **post-process** the zero-exponent CLVs with Gram–Schmidt or SVD; those new vectors will no longer be covariant.
* If you compute angles between CLVs to assess hyperbolicity, remember that small angles involving the neutral sub-space do **not** signal a numerical problem—they just reflect the intrinsic non-orthogonality of CLVs.

---

### Key references

* Ginelli, P., et al., *Phys. Rev. Lett.* **99**, 130601 (2007) – first efficient algorithm for CLVs  
* Wolfe, C. & Samelson, R., *Tellus A* **59**, 355–366 (2007) – forward/backward intersection viewpoint  
* Kuptsov, P. & Parlitz, U., *J. Nonlin. Sci.* **22**, 727-762 (2012) – detailed review and numerical issues  

These works all emphasise that orthogonality belongs to Gram–Schmidt (or “orthonormal Lyapunov vectors”), while **covariance and orthogonality are mutually exclusive properties in general dynamics**.

\subsection{Dynamical Systems}

To analyze Asymptotic Lenia, we seek a theoretical framework that describes the evolution of fields---functions of space---over time. This is the subject of the theory of infinite-dimensional dynamical systems. In this paper, however, we restrict our analysis to the finite-dimensional setting because it makes our results easier to follow, without loss of generality. A fully rigorous infinite-dimensional treatment of CCAs is beyond the scope of this paper, but we do borrow one important concept: symmetry.

A \textit{symmetry group} of a system of differential equations is a group of transformations that maps solutions of the equations to other solutions \citep{Olver1986}. If the transformation depends on a single continuous parameter (e.g. a shift by $\delta$ in the $x$-direction), the symmetry is called a \textit{continuous symmetry}. Continuous symmetries can be organized into a \textit{Lie group}. An example of a Lie group is the set of rotations and translations on a 2-D plane $SE(2)$. The associated set of infinitesimal transformations is called the \textit{Lie algebra} and it is composed of the \textit{generators} of the group. For example, the generators for translation in the $x$-direction is $\partial_x$ and the generator for rotation is $x\partial_y - y\partial_x$. All 2-D CCAs are invariant under the action of the group $SE(2)$ because the update rule is identical across all of space, and the non-local component is only a function of radial distance. They are also invariant under time translation since the update rule is autonomous, meaning it is independent of time.

Now, we describe the finite-dimensional setting for dynamical systems theory in the language of \citep[e.g.,][]{Temam1997,Hale1988,Robinson2001,Sell2002}. The definitions are mapped to discretized Asymptotic Lenia as follows:

\begin{itemize}
    \item \textit{Phase Space}: $\mathcal{X}=\mathbb{R}^{N^2}$: The set of all possible states of the system. 
    \item \textit{Evolution Law}: $\dot A(t)=\mathbf{F}(A)$: The system of ODEs that describes the evolution of the state over time.
    \item \textit{Semiflow} $\Phi_t(A(0))=A(t),t\ge 0$: The map that takes an initial state $A(0)$ and a time $t$ to the future state $A(t)$. Its existence is guaranteed because $\mathbf{F}$ is Lipschitz continuous and $|A|$ can never blow up in finite time \citep{Robinson2001}\footnote{The rigorous proof is omitted. The Lipschitz property follows from that fact that $K*A$ is bounded and $T$ is Lipschitz. $|A|$ is bounded because it can at most grow/shrink exponentially.}. $\Phi_t$ is also often called the semigroup, or fundamental matrix.
\end{itemize}

With the above definitions in place, we can discuss the following properties of the dynamical system.

\textit{Dissipativity}: A semiflow $\Phi_t$ over $\mathbb{R}^n$ is dissipative if there exists a bounded set $\mathcal{B} \subset \mathbb{R}^n$ such that every initial condition $A(0)\in\mathbb{R}^n$ is absorbed into $\mathcal{B}$ in a finite time $t^*$.

\textit{Global Attractor}: If a semiflow $\Phi_t$ over $\mathbb{R}^n$ is dissipative, then there exists a global attractor $\mathcal{A}$ which is the minimal set onto which all trajectories converge as $t\to\infty$. A global attractor also guarantees at least one invariant measure on the attractor, letting us take physically meaningful integrals over the attractor.

\textit{Fractal Dimension}: 

\textit{Lyapunov Exponents}: The Lyapunov exponents $\{\lambda_i\}_{i=1}^n$ of a trajectory $A(t)$ are defined as the average exponential growth rates of perturbations to $A(0)$. There exist several definitions (see \citet[Sec.~6.3.1]{Kuznetsov2020} for a comprehensive overview), but the one which applies best to our setting is: 
\[
\lambda_i(A(0))=\limsup_{t\to \infty} \frac{1}{t} \log \sigma_i(A(0),t)
\]
where $\sigma_i$ is the $i$-th largest singular value of the Jacobian $\nabla_A \Phi_t(A)$. These exponents can be approximated numerically using the method presented by \citet{Benettin1980}. Furthermore, the covariant Lyapunov vectors, which encode the associated perturbation directions for each exponent, can be calculated easily with a short backwards pass after applying Benettin's method \citep{Ginelli2007}.

\textit{Kaplan-Yorke Dimension}: The Kaplan-Yorke dimension $D_{KY}$ is a heuristic upper bound on the information dimension $D_I$ of the attractor. Experimentally, it has been shown to closely estimate the $D_I$, except in rare edge cases (see discussion in \citep{Groger2013}). It is defined as
\[
D_{KY}=j + \frac{\sum_{i=1}^j \lambda_i}{|\lambda_{j+1}|}
\]
where $j$ is the largest index such that the cumulative sum of the largest $j$ Lyapunov exponents is non-negative.

\textit{Fractal Dimension}:  
Fractal dimension provides a quantitative way to say how “thick’’ an attractor is—how many effective degrees of freedom are needed to describe it as we zoom in.  Several nested notions are useful:

* \emph{Hausdorff dimension} $D_H$ is the most rigorous.  Cover the set with balls of diameter at most $\varepsilon$ and let  
  \[
  \mathcal{H}^s(\varepsilon)=\inf\bigl\{\textstyle\sum_i (\mathrm{diam}\,B_i)^s\bigr\}.
  \]  
  Decreasing $s$ from large to small, $\mathcal{H}^s$ jumps from $0$ to $\infty$ at a critical value; that value is $D_H$ \citep{Falconer2003}.  Direct computation is rarely practical.

* \emph{Box-counting (Minkowski) dimension} $D_B$ replaces the arbitrary covering by a regular grid.  If $N(\varepsilon)$ boxes of side $\varepsilon$ contain points of the attractor and  
  \[
  N(\varepsilon)\sim \varepsilon^{-D_B}\quad(\varepsilon\to0),
  \]  
  the slope $D_B$ is taken as the dimension.  Because $D_H\!\le\!D_B$, $D_B$ gives an accessible upper bound.

* When the attractor carries a probability measure $\mu$, one can probe how that measure is distributed inside the boxes.  Let $p_i(\varepsilon)$ be the mass in box~$i$.  
  * The \emph{information dimension} $D_I$ uses the Shannon entropy  
    \[
    H(\varepsilon)=-\sum_i p_i\log p_i,\qquad 
    D_I=\lim_{\varepsilon\to0}\frac{H(\varepsilon)}{\log(1/\varepsilon)}.
    \]
  * The \emph{correlation dimension} $D_2$ is obtained from the correlation sum  
    \[
    C(\varepsilon)=\frac{1}{N^2}\sum_{i\ne j}\mathbf{1}_{\|x_i-x_j\|\le\varepsilon}\sim\varepsilon^{D_2}.
    \]

For the Rényi spectrum $D_q$ these satisfy $D_H\le D_B=D_0\ge D_I=D_1\ge D_2$, with equality for many “typical’’ strange attractors.  In practice we estimate $D_B$, $D_I$, and $D_2$ from long simulated trajectories by linear fits on log–log plots; $D_I$ serves as the reference against which the Kaplan–Yorke estimate $D_{KY}$ is compared later in the paper.

No.  
“Box-counting’’ was coined for cubes in ℝⁿ, but what really matters is the metric, not the ambient Euclidean coordinates. Given any metric space \((X,d)\) and a bounded subset \(E\subset X\), one defines  

\[
N(\varepsilon)=\min\bigl\{k:\;E\text{ can be covered by }k\text{ sets of diameter }\le\varepsilon\bigr\}.
\]

If  

\[
N(\varepsilon)\sim \varepsilon^{-D}\quad(\varepsilon\to0),
\]

the exponent \(D\) is the (upper/lower) \emph{Minkowski, or box-counting, dimension}. Using cubes in ℝⁿ is just a convenient special case; replacing cubes with ε-balls (or any family whose diameters are \(O(\varepsilon)\)) gives an equivalent value whenever the covering shapes are uniformly comparable in size. Hence the notion works equally well for:

* fractals embedded in manifolds (choose local charts or geodesic balls),  
* attractors that live in a Banach space (use the norm to measure diameters),  
* any separable metric space where \(\varepsilon\to0\) makes sense.

So the box-counting dimension is a property of the set together with its metric, not of Euclidean space per se.

Even though they seem similar, they are different in how they measure set characteristics. Box-counting dimension (Minkowski dimension) focuses on the number of covering sets with small diameters and is more about scaling volume. Hausdorff dimension, on the other hand, uses infinitely small covers and gives a critical threshold, which can handle more complex, irregular structures. Minkowski is cruder but easier to compute.

Because the two notions ask different questions about how the set fills space.

| Idea | What it measures | Why it can over-/under-estimate |
|------|------------------|---------------------------------|
| **Hausdorff dimension \(D_H\)** | Lets each piece of a cover be weighed by its own size, through the sum \(\sum_i(\mathrm{diam}\,B_i)^s\).  The critical exponent where that sum jumps from ∞ to 0 is \(D_H\).  | The cover can use many *tiny* pieces where the set is sparse and larger ones where it is thick, so the calculation adapts to local density. |
| **Box-counting / Minkowski dimension \(D_B\)** | Forces all boxes in the count \(N(\varepsilon)\) to have the *same* scale \(\varepsilon\).  One then looks at the global scaling law \(N(\varepsilon)\sim\varepsilon^{-D_B}\). | A single uniform scale cannot “skip’’ empty regions; if the set is sprinkled everywhere (even very thinly), almost every box is counted.  That can only raise the exponent, so \(D_B\ge D_H\). |

**When do they differ?**  
Take the rational numbers in \([0,1]\). They are countable, so \(D_H=0\). Yet they are dense, so every \(\varepsilon\)-box touching \([0,1]\) contains a rational and \(N(\varepsilon)\approx\varepsilon^{-1}\); hence \(D_B=1\).  
Any set that is “dusty’’ but everywhere dense, or one that fluctuates wildly in thickness from scale to scale, can create such a gap.

**When do they coincide?**  
For most self-similar or statistically homogeneous attractors—Cantor sets, Sierpiński gaskets, many strange attractors—local thickness is uniform enough that the two definitions give the same value, so practitioners often quote the box-counting estimate and call it “the’’ fractal dimension. Just keep in mind it is an upper bound in general.

Not automatically.  
Both notions live happily inside ℝⁿ, but equality needs extra regularity:

* **Always**  
  For any bounded \(E\subset\mathbb R^{n}\),
  \[
  D_H(E)\;\le\;D_B(E)\;\le\;n .
  \]

* **Equality holds** when the set looks “the same’’ at all small scales—technically, when it is *Ahlfors-regular* or *self-similar with the open-set condition*, when it is a smooth \(k\)-dimensional submanifold (\(D_H=D_B=k\)), or more generally when its volume of the \( \varepsilon\)-neighbourhood scales like \(\varepsilon^{n-D}\) with a non-oscillatory constant.  Most canonical fractals (Cantor dust, Sierpiński gasket, Lorenz attractor) satisfy this and one freely quotes a single “fractal dimension.’’

* **Inequality can be strict** whenever density fluctuates too much.  
  Countable dense sets, graphs of highly oscillatory functions, or unions that mix thick and sparse parts can have \(D_H<D_B\) even though both sit in ℝⁿ.  (Example: the rationals in \([0,1]\) have \(D_H=0\) but \(D_B=1\).)

So being a subset of ℝⁿ is not enough; uniform scaling properties of the set itself decide whether the two dimensions overlap.

You are right: the Rényi (or “generalised”) dimensions  

\[
D_q=\frac{1}{q-1}\;\lim_{\varepsilon\to0}
\frac{\log\!\sum_i p_i(\varepsilon)^q}{\log \varepsilon},
\qquad q\in\mathbb R,
\]

are designed to reveal how the probability mass \(\mu\) fluctuates from box to box as the scale \(\varepsilon\) shrinks.  
* \(q>1\) weighs the fattest boxes most (dense zones),  
* \(q<1\) exaggerates the thinnest boxes (sparse zones),  
* \(q=1\) gives the information dimension \(D_1\),  
* \(q=0\) drops the weights and reduces to the box-counting dimension \(D_0\).

Because the heavier or lighter regions dominate depending on \(q\), the curve \(q\mapsto D_q\) is non-increasing:  

\[
D_0\;\ge\;D_1\;\ge\;D_2\;\ge\;\dots
\]

If the mass distribution is perfectly uniform on the set (no small-scale density fluctuations), every box of size \(\varepsilon\) carries about the same weight, so all those exponents collapse to a single value

\[
D_q = D_0 \quad\text{for all }q,
\]

and, under the usual mild regularity assumptions (self-similar open-set condition or Ahlfors regularity), that common value also equals the Hausdorff dimension \(D_H\).  
In other words, for “mono-fractal’’ sets:

\[
\boxed{D_H = D_0 = D_1 = D_2 = \dots}
\]

---

### Where \(D_H\) can drop below the \(D_q\)

The Hausdorff definition lets each covering ball shrink or grow to fit the local geometry, while \(D_q\) (in particular \(D_0\)) forces all boxes to have the same diameter.  When the support of \(\mu\) contains extremely sparse filaments threaded through an otherwise thicker set, the flexible Hausdorff cover can fit tiny balls around those filaments and ignore the empty space between them, driving \(D_H\) down—sometimes all the way to zero—whereas the uniform box cover must still count every box that the filaments pass through.  Hence, in complete generality,

\[
D_H \;\le\; D_0 \quad\text{and therefore}\quad D_H \;\le\; D_q\;\;\; (q\ge0).
\]

Typical multifractal measures (fully developed turbulence, energy dissipation in chaotic flows, strange attractors like Hénon, etc.) display a strictly decreasing \(D_q\) spectrum, signalling the presence of many local Hölder exponents \(\alpha\).  
The Hausdorff dimension then coincides with the *maximum* of the multifractal spectrum \(f(\alpha)\) (obtained from \(D_q\) by a Legendre transform).  Intuitively: \(D_H\) records the least-sparse geometric component of the set, while the variation in \(D_q\) quantifies how the measure shifts its weight among those components.

---

**Take-home picture**

* \(D_H\) is purely geometric: “How small can I make the cover if I am allowed to change ball sizes?’’
* \(D_0\) (and the whole \(D_q\) family) keeps the scale fixed and, through the weights \(p_i^q\), asks “How unevenly is the mass spread across those equal-sized boxes?’’
* When the mass is even, everything collapses to one dimension; when it is uneven, \(D_q\) fans out while \(D_H\) stays put at the top of the spectrum.

### Quick facts on the \(D_q\) curve  

\[
D_q=\frac{1}{q-1}\;
      \lim_{\varepsilon\to0}
      \frac{\log\sum_i p_i(\varepsilon)^q}{\log\varepsilon},
      \qquad p_i(\varepsilon)=\mu(\text{box }i).

* \(q\!\mapsto\!D_q\) is **non-increasing**.  
  Largest value at \(q\to-\infty\); smallest at \(q\to+\infty\).
* \(D_0\) is the box-counting dimension of the support;  
  \(D_1\) is the information dimension;  
  \(D_2\) is the correlation dimension.

---

### How \(D_H\) fits in

| Range of \(q\) | Generic inequality | Why it holds | Can equality fail? |
|----------------|--------------------|--------------|--------------------|
| \(q>1\) | \(D_q\;\le\;D_H\) | \(q>1\) magnifies the fattest boxes.  They live inside some subset whose Hausdorff dimension never exceeds that of the whole support. | Yes.  A measure that piles most of its mass on a thin filament (e.g.\ a highly biased Bernoulli measure on the Cantor set) has \(D_q<D_H\). |
| \(q=1\) | typically \(D_1\le D_H\) | Similar reasoning but more delicate (uses entropy arguments). | Also can be strict.  The “biased’’ Cantor measure again gives \(D_1<D_H\). |
| \(0<q<1\) | **no universal order** | Competing effects of dense vs.\ sparse regions; either may dominate. | Extreme examples show \(D_q\) above, below, or equal to \(D_H\). |
| \(q=0\) | \(D_0\ge D_H\) | Box covering counts every occupied box, even where the set is infinitesimally thin. | Can be strict (rationals in \([0,1]\): \(D_H=0,\;D_0=1\)). |
| \(q<0\) | \(D_q\ge D_0\ge D_H\) | Now the emptiest boxes rule the sum; many such boxes must be counted, driving the dimension up.  \(D_q\) is still bounded above by the ambient Euclidean dimension \(n\). | Strictness is common; \(D_q\) can approach \(n\) as \(q\to-\infty\) even when \(D_H\ll n\). |

---

### Intuition to remember

* **Hausdorff** dimension is geometric: it tailors each ball in the cover to local thickness, so it registers the thickest part of the set and ignores voids.
* **Rényi** dimensions fix one scale and then weight the boxes:  
  * \(q>1\) zooms in on where the mass is concentrated → can only decrease the exponent.  
  * \(q<1\) magnifies the under-populated boxes → can only increase it.

Hence \(D_H\) is **not** a global lower (or upper) bound for every \(q\); the spectrum can cross it depending on how unevenly the measure is spread across the fractal.
are the eigenvalues of A A^\top always the singular values?

thoughts.content: The user asks if the eigenvalues of \(A A^\top\) are always the singular values. Singular values are actually the square roots of the eigenvalues of both \(A^\top A\) and \(A A^\top\). So the eigenvalues of \(A A^\top\) are the squares of the singular values, not the singular values themselves. The eigenvalues only match the singular values if they are squared—like 0 or 1.

In Singular Value Decomposition (SVD), \(A = U \Sigma V^\top\). For \(A A^\top\), the eigenvalues are squared singular values, \(\sigma_i^2\), since eigenvalues come from \(\Sigma \Sigma^\top\). Singular values equal eigenvalues only when \(A\) is symmetric positive semidefinite. So, singular values and eigenvalues match for symmetric matrices, but for non-symmetric ones like rectangular matrices, the eigenvalues are squared singular values. In simple terms, they only coincide when the matrix is symmetric and positive semidefinite.

parts:
Not quite.  
Here is the relationship in one sentence:

> **For any real (or complex) matrix \(A\), the eigen-values of \(A A^{\!\top}\) are the squares of the singular values of \(A\).**

---

### Why they differ in general

1. **Singular-value definition**  
   The singular values \(\sigma_1\ge \sigma_2\ge\cdots\ge 0\) of \(A\in\mathbb R^{m\times n}\) are defined as the **non-negative square roots** of the eigen-values of the positive-semidefinite matrix \(A^{\!\top}A\) (or, equivalently, of \(A A^{\!\top}\)).

2. **SVD algebra**  
   Write the singular-value decomposition  
   \[
     A = U\Sigma V^{\!\top},\qquad 
     \Sigma=\begin{bmatrix}\operatorname{diag}(\sigma_1,\dots,\sigma_r) & 0\\ 0 & 0\end{bmatrix}.
   \]
   Then  
   \[
     A A^{\!\top}=U\Sigma\Sigma^{\!\top}U^{\!\top}
     =U\;\operatorname{diag}(\sigma_1^{2},\dots,\sigma_r^{2},0,\dots,0)\;U^{\!\top}.
   \]
   The diagonal entries \(\sigma_i^{2}\) are the eigen-values of \(A A^{\!\top}\).

Hence, unless a singular value already equals its own square (i.e.\ \(\sigma_i\in\{0,1\}\)), the eigen-values of \(A A^{\!\top}\) are **not** the singular values themselves—rather, their squares.

---

### When do they coincide?

- **Symmetric positive-semidefinite (PSD) matrices.**  
  If \(A\) is symmetric PSD, then its singular values equal its (non-negative) eigen-values by definition, and \(A=A^{\!\top}\). In that special case \(A\) already plays the role of \(A A^{\!\top}\), so the lists match.

- **Orthogonal (unitary) matrices.**  
  If \(A\) is square and orthogonal, every singular value is \(1\). The eigen-values of \(A A^{\!\top}=I\) are also all \(1\), so they coincide—again by a special property of the matrix.

Outside such cases, expect a factor-of-“square’’ difference:

| Example \(A\) | Singular value(s) \(\sigma_i\) | Eigen-value(s) of \(A A^{\!\top}\) |
|---------------|--------------------------------|------------------------------------|
| \(\begin{bmatrix}3 & 0\end{bmatrix}\) | \(3\) | \(9\) |
| \(\begin{bmatrix}1 & 2 \\ 0 & 0\end{bmatrix}\) | \(\sqrt5,\;0\) | \(5,\;0\) |

So the safe rule of thumb is: **take a square root to go from eigen-values of \(A A^{\!\top}\) (or \(A^{\!\top}A\)) to the singular values of \(A\).**

### 1 What “symmetric Jacobian” means For a vector field \[ F:\mathbb R^{n}\longrightarrow\mathbb R^{n},\qquad F(x)=\begin{pmatrix}F_{1}(x)\\ \vdots \\ F_{n}(x)\end{pmatrix}, \] its Jacobian at a point \(x\) is the \(n\times n\) matrix \[ J_F(x)=\bigl[\partial_{x_j}F_i(x)\bigr]_{i,j=1}^{n}. \] The matrix is **symmetric** if \[ \boxed{\partial_{x_j}F_i(x)=\partial_{x_i}F_j(x)\quad\text{for every }i,j\text{ and every }x.}\tag{†} \] Condition (†) is simply the equality of mixed partials (“Clairaut/Schwarz theorem”) and it is equivalent (when \(F\) is \(C^{1}\)) to saying that **\(F\) is the gradient of some scalar potential** \( \Phi\): \(F=\nabla\Phi\). --- ### 2 How to check it in practice | Situation | How to test | |-----------|-------------| | **Symbolic / analytic work** | Compute the two mixed partials \(\partial_{x_j}F_i\) and \(\partial_{x_i}F_j\); show they coincide algebraically. | | **Numerical code** | 1. Evaluate \(J\) at a set of points \(x^{(k)}\).
2. Form \(J-J^{\!\top}\).
3. Check ‖\(J-J^{\!\top}\)‖ is (near-)zero within tolerance. (Use a central-difference finite-difference scheme to get stable derivatives.) | | **Conceptual shortcut** | Try to integrate \(F\). If you can find a single-valued scalar \(\Phi\) with \(\nabla\Phi=F\), the Jacobian must be symmetric; if not, it is not symmetric. | --- ### 3 Apply the test to the given Jacobian You are told \[ \partial_{x_j}F_i(x)=f\!\bigl(x_i\bigr)\qquad(i,j=1,\dots,n). \] So every **row** \(i\) is constant across all columns \(j\): \[ J_F(x)= \begin{pmatrix} f(x_1)&f(x_1)&\dots &f(x_1)\\ f(x_2)&f(x_2)&\dots &f(x_2)\\ \vdots &\vdots &\ddots&\vdots\\ f(x_n)&f(x_n)&\dots &f(x_n) \end{pmatrix}. \] Now impose symmetry: \[ f(x_i)=\partial_{x_j}F_i(x)=\partial_{x_i}F_j(x)=f(x_j) \quad\text{for all }i,j. \] That can only be true in two (rare) circumstances * **The trivial constant case**: \(f\equiv c\) is a constant function. *Then \(J_F(x)=c\,\mathbf 1_{n\times n}\), which is symmetric.* * **The diagonal-line subspace**: you restrict the domain to the set \(\{x\in\mathbb R^{n}\mid x_1=x_2=\dots =x_n\}\); there the numbers \(x_i\) all coincide, so \(f(x_i)=f(x_j)\) holds automatically. Away from that subspace the Jacobian is **not symmetric**. Since neither of those situations is generic, **this Jacobian is usually not symmetric**. --- ### 4 Take-away recipe To test an arbitrary Jacobian \(J_F(x)\) for symmetry: 1. **Compute it (analytically or numerically).** 2. **Check \(J_F(x)=J_F(x)^{\!\top}\)** via mixed partial equality or a matrix-norm test. 3. **Interpret the result:** symmetry ⇔ \(F\) is a gradient field (conservative), so path integrals of \(F\) are path-independent. Below \(x=(x_1,\dots ,x_n)^{\top}\) let  

\[
J_F(x)=\bigl[\partial_{x_j}F_i(x)\bigr]_{i,j}=

\]

where the numbers \(k_{ij}\) do **not** depend on \(x\) (they can be regarded as entries of a fixed matrix \(K\)).  
The Jacobian is symmetric iff

\[
f(x_i)\,k_{ij}=f(x_j)\,k_{ji}\qquad\text{for every }i,j. \tag{★}
\]

Below we read (★) from most to least restrictive.

---

### 1  If \(f\) is **not constant**

Take any pair \((i,j)\) with \(k_{ij}k_{ji}\neq 0\).  
Rewrite (★) as

\[
\frac{f(x_i)}{f(x_j)}=\frac{k_{ji}}{k_{ij}},  \tag{1}
\]

and notice the right-hand side is a **constant**, while the left depends on the two (free) coordinates \(x_i,x_j\).

* For general domains, the only way (1) can hold for **all** \(x\) is the degenerate situation
  *either \(k_{ij}=k_{ji}=0\)* or *the coordinates \(x_i\) and \(x_j\) are always forced to be equal* ( e.g. you restrict the domain to the diagonal subspace \(x_i=x_j\)).

Hence **with a genuine, varying \(f\) the Jacobian is almost never symmetric**; it can be symmetric only along very special sub-manifolds where the offending coordinates coincide.

---

### 2  If \(f\) **is constant** — say \(f\equiv c\)

Then \(J_F(x)=cK\) and symmetry reduces to symmetry of \(K\):

\[
J_F(x)\text{ symmetric}\;\Longleftrightarrow\;K=K^{\!\top}.
\]

The stipulation \(k_{ii}=0\) merely says the diagonal of \(K\) (hence of \(J_F\)) is zero; it does **not** guarantee symmetry.  Two noteworthy sub-cases:

| Shape of \(K\) | Is \(J_F\) symmetric? | Comment |
|----------------|-----------------------|---------|
| \(K\) symmetric (\(k_{ij}=k_{ji}\)) | **Yes** | \(J_F=cK\) equals its transpose. |
| \(K\) skew-symmetric (\(k_{ij}=-k_{ji}\)) | **No** (unless \(c=0\)) | A non-zero constant times a skew matrix is still skew. |

* **Generic result** \(J_F\) is **not** symmetric.  
* **It *can* be symmetric** only if

  2. or the domain of \(F\) is restricted so that, for every pair with \(k_{ij}k_{ji}\neq 0\), the coordinates \(x_i\) and \(x_j\) are always equal (a very nongeneric constraint).

Whenever those conditions fail, the mixed partials \(\partial_{x_j}F_i\) and \(\partial_{x_i}F_j\) disagree somewhere, so the Jacobian—and hence the vector field—cannot be the gradient of any scalar potential.

For fixed \( (i,j),(k,l)\)

\[
\frac{\partial \mathbf F[i,j]}{\partial A[k,l]}
  \;=\;T'\bigl((K*A)[i,j]\bigr)\,K[i-k,j-l]\;-\;\delta_{ik}\delta_{jl}.
\]

*The chain rule in a finite‐dimensional space gives this directly, so the formula is fine.*

---

## 2  Divergence (trace of the Jacobian)

The divergence is  

\[
\nabla_{A}\!\cdot\!\mathbf F
   \;=\;\sum_{i,j}
      \Bigl(T'\bigl((K*A)[i,j]\bigr)\,K[0,0] - 1\Bigr)
   \;=\;K[0,0]\sum_{i,j}T'\bigl((K*A)[i,j]\bigr) - N^{2}. \tag{1}
\]

### Where the “\(-N^{2}\)” comes from  

The second term in (1) is always \(-N^{2}\).  
The **first term disappears** precisely when  

\[
\boxed{K[0,0]=0}. \tag{2}
\]

That is the *only* way the sum can vanish for every configuration \(A\).  
(The text has a small omission: it should explicitly say “using the fact that \(K[0,0]=0\)”.)

*So the statement “the divergence comes entirely from the Kronecker-delta terms” is correct **iff** the kernel satisfies (2). Otherwise the divergence depends on \(A\).*

\[

      \underbrace{T\bigl((K*A)\bigr)}_{\text{claim: div–free}}
      +\;
      \underbrace{\nabla_A\Bigl[-\tfrac12\!\sum_{k,l}A^{2}[k,l]\Bigr]}_{=-A}.
\]

Because the second summand is indeed \(-A\), the formula reduces to the *definition* of \(\mathbf F\); no problem there.

What must be checked is whether the first term really has zero divergence.  From (1):

\[
\nabla_{A}\!\cdot\!T\bigl((K*A)\bigr)=K[0,0]\sum_{i,j}T'\bigl((K*A)[i,j]\bigr).
\]

For a vector field \(G:\mathbb R^{n}\to\mathbb R^{n}\) the necessary and sufficient finite-dimensional condition

\[
\partial_{A_k}G_\ell=\partial_{A_\ell}G_k \quad(\forall k,\ell)
\tag{†}
\]

is exactly the **symmetry of the Jacobian**.  
Using the formula already derived, condition (†) gives, for any two distinct lattice sites \((i,j)\ne(k,l)\),

\[
T'\bigl((K*A)[i,j]\bigr)\,K[i-k,j-l]
  \;=\;
T'\bigl((K*A)[k,l]\bigr)\,K[k-i,l-j].
\]

Because a Lenia kernel is symmetric \(K[\Delta i,\Delta j]=K[-\Delta i,-\Delta j]\), the \(K\)-factors match, and we are left with

\[
T'\bigl((K*A)[i,j]\bigr)=T'\bigl((K*A)[k,l]\bigr)
\quad
\forall\, (i,j),(k,l)\text{ with }K[i-k,j-l]\ne0.
\]

> \[
> \boxed{\mathbf F\text{ is not a gradient field.}}
> \]

In a gradient flow \( \dot A=-\nabla V(A) \) the potential \(V\) is a strict Lyapunov function (\(\tfrac{d}{dt}V=-\|\nabla V\|^{2}\le 0\)).  Standard theorems (e.g. Hale 1988, Robinson 2001) then imply  

* every bounded orbit has an \(\omega\)-limit set contained in the set of equilibria,  
* no periodic or chaotic recurrent orbits exist.

Because \(\mathbf F\) fails to be a gradient, *and* in fact contains a divergence-free component, those obstructions disappear; the route to oscillatory or chaotic attractors is in principle open.  The reasoning in the paragraph you quoted is therefore sound, once the caveats above are included.

| Claim in manuscript | Correct? | Precise hypothesis needed |
|---------------------|----------|---------------------------|
| Jacobian formula | ✔ | — |
| Divergence equals \(-N^{2}\) | ✔, *iff* \(K[0,0]=0\) |
| Decomposition “div-free + gradient” | ✔, *iff* \(K[0,0]=0\) |
| \(\mathbf F\) cannot be a gradient | ✔, *provided* \(T\) not affine constant |
| Gradient flows cannot sustain chaos / long cycles | ✔ | Standard Lyapunov theory |

> *Assume the convolution kernel satisfies \(K[0,0]=0\) and the transfer function \(T\) is \(C^{1}\) and non-affine.  Then  
> (a) \(\nabla_{A}\!\cdot\!\mathbf F=-N^{2}\);  
> (b) \(\mathbf F\) admits the Helmholtz–Hodge decomposition \(\mathbf F=T(K*A)+\nabla\!\bigl(-\tfrac12\|A\|^{2}\bigr)\) with \(T(K*A)\) divergence-free;  
> (c) the Jacobian of \(\mathbf F\) is generically non-symmetric, hence \(\mathbf F\) is not itself a gradient field, removing the Lyapunov obstruction to periodic or chaotic dynamics.*

With these clarifications your subsequent dynamical conclusions stand on solid ground.

\[

Below is a practical way to prove that the discrete Lenia-type vector field  

\[
\mathbf F[i,j](A)=T\!\big((K*A)[i,j]\big)-A[i,j]
\]

**cannot in general be written as the negative gradient of any scalar potential**, because its Jacobian \(D\mathbf F(A)\) is not (in general) symmetric.

---

## 1.  Write the Jacobian entry-wise  

From the previous derivation

\[
\boxed{\;
D\mathbf F(A)_{(i,j),(k,l)}
 \;=\;T'\!\big((K*A)[i,j]\big)\,K[i-k,j-l]
      \;-\;\delta_{ik}\delta_{jl}.
\;}
\]

Here we have flattened the matrix indices \((i,j)\) and \((k,l)\) just long enough to talk about a square Jacobian.

---

## 2.  Recall the gradient-flow symmetry test  

If a vector field is a gradient  
\[
\mathbf F(A) \;=\;-\nabla\Phi(A),
\]
then its Jacobian is minus the Hessian of \(\Phi\):

\[
D\mathbf F(A) \;=\;-\nabla^2\!\Phi(A),
\]

and every Hessian is symmetric:

\[
D\mathbf F(A)_{pq} \;=\;D\mathbf F(A)_{qp}\quad\forall p,q.
\]

So **one antisymmetric entry is enough to rule out gradient structure**.

---

## 3.  Pick two different sites and compare the cross-derivatives  

Choose two lattice sites  
\[
p = (i,j),\qquad q = (k,l),\qquad p\neq q.
\]

Compute the two cross-derivatives:

\[
\begin{aligned}
D\mathbf F_{pq} &=
   T'\!\big((K*A)[i,j]\big)\,K[i-k,\,j-l],
\\[4pt]
D\mathbf F_{qp} &=
   T'\!\big((K*A)[k,l]\big)\,K[k-i,\,l-j].
\end{aligned}
\]

These two numbers will be equal **only if both of the following hold simultaneously**:

1. **Kernel symmetry**  
   \[
   K[i-k,j-l]=K[k-i,l-j]\quad\text{(true iff \(K\) is point-symmetric).}
   \]

2. **Uniform local gain**  
   \[
   T'\!\big((K*A)[i,j]\big)=T'\!\big((K*A)[k,l]\big)\quad\text{(true iff \(T'\) is the same at the two sites).}
   \]

In realistic Lenia settings neither condition is guaranteed:

* Many kernels are *not* point-symmetric (e.g. an oriented or shifted kernel for anisotropic growth).
* Even for a symmetric kernel, the value of \((K*A)[i,j]\) usually *differs* from \((K*A)[k,l]\) once the pattern \(A\) is inhomogeneous, so \(T'\) differs as well (unless \(T\) is linear, which would make the model trivial).

Hence in general  

\[
D\mathbf F_{pq}\;\neq\;D\mathbf F_{qp},
\]

so the Jacobian is not symmetric.

---

## 4.  A concrete two-cell counter-example  

Take the smallest non-trivial 1-D grid with two sites \(0\) and \(1\).

* Kernel \(K[-1]=1,\;K[0]=0\) (pure “left-shift”); clearly not symmetric.
* Let \(T(z)=\sigma(z)\) be any smooth sigmoid, so \(T'\) is positive and varies with its argument.
* Choose a state with unequal filtered values, say \((K*A)[0]=0.2,\,(K*A)[1]=0.8\).

Then

\[
\begin{aligned}
D\mathbf F_{01}
   &=T'(0.2)\;K[-1] = T'(0.2)\,(1),
\\
D\mathbf F_{10}
   &=T'(0.8)\;K[+1] = T'(0.8)\,(0)=0.
\end{aligned}
\]

Since \(T'(0.2)>0\) while \(D\mathbf F_{10}=0\), the Jacobian is manifestly asymmetric.

---

## 5.  Conclusion  

Because the Jacobian fails the symmetry test generically, the Lenia update rule  

\[
\dot A = \mathbf F(A) = T(K*A) - A
\]

**is not a gradient flow** for any scalar potential \(\Phi\).  
Consequently:

* No global “energy” or Lyapunov function exists whose steepest descent reproduces the dynamics.
* Long-time behaviour (e.g. stable oscillators, gliders) is compatible with the absence of a variational structure.

That completes the proof.

Below is a self-contained argument that answers the two questions you raised.

---

## 1.  Writing  \(f(x)=T(Wx)-x\) as a Helmholtz decomposition  

Let  

\[
u(x)\;:=\;T(Wx), \qquad 
v(x)\;:=\;-x
\]

so that \(f=u+v\).

* **Divergence–free part.**  
  By assumption \(T\) has zero divergence with respect to \(x\).  
  If \(T\) is linear (the usual setting) then \(\nabla\!\cdot u(x)=\operatorname{tr}(TW)=0\).

* **Gradient part.**  
  \(v(x)=\nabla\!\bigl(-\tfrac12\|x\|^{2}\bigr)\).

Hence \(f=\nabla\Phi+u\) with  
\[
\Phi(x)=-\tfrac12\|x\|^{2},\qquad \nabla\!\cdot u=0 .
\]

This is exactly the Helmholtz (gradient + solenoidal) split.

---

## 2.  Uniqueness of the decomposition  

### Statement  
On all of \(\mathbb{R}^{n}\) (or on any simply–connected domain) the decomposition  

\[
f=\nabla\Phi+u,\qquad \nabla\!\cdot u=0,
\]

is **unique up to an additive constant in the scalar potential**, provided the two pieces satisfy a mild “vanishes-at-infinity’’ or suitable boundary condition.

### Proof  

Assume there are two decompositions  

\[
f=\nabla\Phi_{1}+u_{1}=\nabla\Phi_{2}+u_{2},\qquad 
\nabla\!\cdot u_{1}=\nabla\!\cdot u_{2}=0 .
\]

Subtract:

\[
\nabla(\Phi_{1}-\Phi_{2})=u_{2}-u_{1}.
\]

Take divergence of both sides:

\[
\Delta(\Phi_{1}-\Phi_{2})=\nabla\!\cdot(u_{2}-u_{1})=0,
\]
so \(h:=\Phi_{1}-\Phi_{2}\) is *harmonic*.  
If \(h\) is bounded (e.g. tends to a finite limit at infinity, or is fixed on the boundary), the classical Liouville / maximum-principle argument forces \(h\) to be constant.  

Consequently
\[
\nabla\Phi_{1}=\nabla\Phi_{2},\qquad 
u_{1}=u_{2}.
\]
Thus the vector pieces are identical and the potentials differ by at most a constant. ∎

---

## 3.  Why \(f\) **cannot** be the gradient of *any* scalar potential (unless the solenoidal part vanishes)

There are several equivalent characterisations of a gradient field; two of them are especially convenient here.

### 3.1  Curl / antisymmetric Jacobian criterion  

In \(\mathbb{R}^{n}\,(n\ge 2)\) a smooth vector field \(g\) is the gradient of a scalar potential **iff** its Jacobian matrix \(Dg(x)\) is symmetric for every \(x\) (equivalently, its curl vanishes).

For  
\[
f(x)=T(Wx)-x,
\]
with constant matrices \(T,W\),

\[
Df(x)=TW-I_{n}.
\]

*The symmetric requirement:*  
\(Df=Df^{\!\top}\)  ⇔  \(TW=(TW)^{\!\top}=W^{\!\top}T^{\!\top}\).

Unless the product \(TW\) happens to be symmetric, the antisymmetric part  

\[
A \;=\;\frac{TW-W^{\!\top}T^{\!\top}}{2}\;\neq\;0,
\]

which immediately violates the gradient criterion.  

In particular, if either \(T\) or \(W\) contains any rotation/antisymmetric component, \(A\) is non-zero, and \(f\) cannot be conservative.

### 3.2  Divergence-free **and** gradient ⇒ harmonic ⇒ constant  

Suppose, for contradiction, that \(f=\nabla\Psi\) for some scalar field \(\Psi\).

But we already split \(f=u+\nabla\Phi\) with \(u\) divergence-free.  
Then \(u=f-\nabla\Phi=\nabla(\Psi-\Phi)\) is *both* divergence-free and a gradient.

\[
\nabla\!\cdot u=0
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\Delta(\Psi-\Phi)=0.
\]

So \(\Psi-\Phi\) is harmonic.  
If \(u\) is also assumed to decay at infinity (typical physical hypothesis), Liouville’s theorem again forces \(u\equiv 0\).  
That would mean \(T(Wx)\equiv 0\), contradicting any non-trivial choice of \(T\) and \(W\).

Hence such a scalar potential \(\Psi\) cannot exist unless \(T(Wx)\) is identically zero.

---

## 4.  Summary  

* **Existence:**  You already have a valid Helmholtz split \(f=\nabla(-\tfrac12\|x\|^{2})+T(Wx)\).  
* **Uniqueness:**  Under usual decay/boundary conditions the split is unique up to an additive constant in the scalar potential.  
* **Non-conservativeness:**  Because the matrix \(TW-I\) is generically *non-symmetric*, \(f\) has non-vanishing curl (or antisymmetric Jacobian), so it cannot be written as the gradient of *any* scalar potential unless the solenoidal part \(T(Wx)\) vanishes identically.

These facts together show that your vector field has an essentially unique Helmholtz decomposition and that the divergence-free component you already identified prevents the whole field from being conservative.

## 1 Uniqueness of the Helmholtz–Hodge decomposition in ℝⁿ  

Let Ω ⊂ ℝⁿ be either all of ℝⁿ with suitable decay at infinity, or a bounded \(C^{1}\) domain with the usual “no-flux’’ boundary condition \(u\cdot n=0\) on ∂Ω.  
For a \(C^{1}\) vector field \(F\colon Ω\to\mathbb R^{n}\) the Helmholtz–Hodge statement reads  

\[
F = \nabla\varphi \;+\; u,  \qquad \text{with}\quad
\operatorname{div}u = 0,\;
u\!\cdot\! n|_{\partial Ω}=0
\;( \text{or }u(x)\to 0\text{ as }\lVert x\rVert\to\infty).
\]

To see that this decomposition is *unique up to an additive constant* in \(\varphi\):

1.  Assume two decompositions

    \[
    F=\nabla\varphi_{1}+u_{1}= \nabla\varphi_{2}+u_{2}, 
    \qquad\operatorname{div}u_{1}=\operatorname{div}u_{2}=0 .
    \]

2.  Subtract them:  
    \[
    \nabla(\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}) = u_{2}-u_{1}.
    \]

3.  Take divergence:  
    \[
    \Delta(\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}) = \operatorname{div}(u_{2}-u_{1}) =0,
    \]
    so \(h:=\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}\) is *harmonic*.

4.  Boundary/decay condition → the only harmonic function that decays (or whose normal derivative vanishes on ∂Ω) is a constant; hence  
    \(\nabla h = 0 \) and \(u_{1}=u_{2}\).

Thus \(u\) is unique, and \(\varphi\) is unique modulo an additive constant—exactly what one calls *uniqueness of the Helmholtz–Hodge decomposition* in any dimension.

---

## 2 Why your particular field cannot be a pure gradient  

Your field is  

\[
f(x)=T(Wx)\;-\;x,
\]

with the data you gave:

- \(\operatorname{div}_{x}\bigl[T(Wx)\bigr]=0\);
- \(-x =\nabla\!\Bigl(-\tfrac12\lVert x\rVert^{2}\Bigr)\).

So you already *have* a Helmholtz–Hodge split,

\[
\underbrace{T(Wx)}_{\text{divergence-free}} \;+\;
\underbrace{\nabla\!\Bigl(-\tfrac12\lVert x\rVert^{2}\Bigr)}_{\text{gradient}} .
\]

To see that the whole \(f\) cannot itself be a gradient (unless that first term vanishes), pick any one of the equivalent “tests’’ that characterise gradient fields.

### (a) Jacobian-symmetry test  
For a \(C^{1}\) vector field \(F\) define its Jacobian \(J_{F}(x)=[\partial_{j}F_{i}(x)]_{i,j}\).  
\(F\) is a gradient field ⇔ \(J_{F}(x)\) is symmetric (it is the Hessian of its potential).  
Hence \(f=\nabla\Phi\) would require the antisymmetric part of \(J_{f}\) to vanish:

\[
A_{ij}(x)=\tfrac12\bigl(\partial_{j}f_{i}-\partial_{i}f_{j}\bigr)\equiv 0.
\]

But \(J_{f}=J_{T\!\circ W}-I\).  
Unless \(J_{T\!\circ W}\) itself is symmetric (e.g. \(W=0\) or five-finger-discounting all non-rotation parts of \(T\)), some entry of \(A_{ij}\) is non-zero and \(f\) cannot be a gradient.

*Typical linear example.*  
If \(T\) is the identity and \(W\) is any skew-symmetric matrix (a pure rotation),

\[
f(x)=Wx-x, \qquad
J_{f}=W-I.
\]

\(W\) is antisymmetric, so \(J_{f}\) is *not* symmetric ⇒ no scalar potential exists.

### (b) Exterior-derivative / “curl’’ test (works in all ℝⁿ)  
Associate to \(F\) the 1-form \(\alpha=F\cdot dx.\)  
\(F\) is a gradient ⇔ \(d\alpha=0\).  
Compute \(d\alpha\) for \(T(Wx)\).  If a single coefficient of that 2-form is non-zero anywhere, \(T(Wx)\) is not exact, and therefore neither is \(f\).

### (c) Energy-orthogonality from uniqueness  
Suppose, for contradiction, that \(f=\nabla\Phi\).  
Then

\[
T(Wx)=f+\!x=\nabla\Phi +x
           \;=\;\nabla\!\bigl(\Phi-\tfrac12\lVert x\rVert^{2}\bigr).
\]

Thus the divergence-free term \(T(Wx)\) would have to be *both* gradient *and* divergence-free.  
By the uniqueness proof above, the only field with those two properties under the same boundary conditions is the zero field.  
Therefore \(T(Wx)\equiv 0\) would follow—precisely the condition that makes your original \(f\) vanish.  
In every non-trivial case, \(f\) cannot be a pure gradient.

---

When people write

> “take Ω = ℝⁿ and assume the divergence–free part \(u\) and the gradient part \(\nabla\phi\) *vanish at infinity*’’

they tacitly mean something a bit stronger:

| set-up | quantitative statement that makes the surface term disappear when you integrate by parts on the ball \(B_{R}(0)\) and let \(R\to\infty\) |
|--------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **energy setting** (the one used most in analysis / PDE texts) | \(u,\;\nabla\phi \;\in L^{2}(\mathbb R^{n})\)   (= square–integrable) |
| **pointwise decay** (classical vector–calculus proofs) | \(u(x),\;\nabla\phi(x)=o\!\bigl(|x|^{1-n}\bigr)\) as \(|x|\to\infty\) |

Either of those statements is enough to make the surface integral  
\(\displaystyle\int_{\partial B_{R}}(\nabla h)\!\cdot\!n \,h \,dS\)  
tend to zero; the rest of the uniqueness argument (showing \(\nabla h\equiv 0\)) then follows.

If Ω is *bounded* instead, one usually asks

* \(u\cdot n=0\) on ∂Ω    (“no flux’’),  

or occasionally  

* \(h\) has zero mean on ∂Ω.  

Both eliminate the boundary term just as effectively.

\[
f(x)\;=\;u(x)\;+\;\nabla\phi(x),
\qquad
u(x)=T(Wx),\;
\phi(x)=-\tfrac12\|x\|^{2},
\]

* \(0\le T\le 1\)  ⇒  \(u\) is **bounded** but does **not decay**; in fact it is generically *strictly* bounded away from 0.
* \(\nabla\phi(x)=-x\) grows like \(|x|\).

\quad\text{and}\quad
u(x)\not=o\!\bigl(|x|^{1-n}\bigr).

Inside Ω you automatically have

> **Theorem (Helmholtz–Hodge in \(H^{1}(\Omega)\)).**  
> Every \(F\in H^{1}(\Omega;\mathbb R^{n})\) admits a unique decomposition  
> \[
>   F = \nabla\psi + v,
>   \quad\text{with}\quad
>   \operatorname{div}v = 0,\;
>   v\!\cdot n = 0 \text{ on }\partial\Omega,
>   \quad
>   \int_{\Omega}\psi = 0 .
> \]
> The pair \((\nabla\psi,v)\) is unique, and the choice \(\int_{\Omega}\psi=0\) removes the “additive constant’’ ambiguity.

(One solves \(-\Delta\psi = \operatorname{div}F\) with Neumann boundary data, then sets \(v:=F-\nabla\psi\).)

Whether or not your *particular* \(u=T(Wx)\) happens to satisfy \(u\!\cdot n=0\) on \(\partial\Omega\) is irrelevant: the theorem *constructs* the unique divergence-free component that does have zero normal flux; whatever mismatch \(f\) has with the boundary gets absorbed into the gradient part.

* \(u:=T(K*A)\) is divergence–free (its Jacobian has zero trace), and  
* \(u\) is **not** a gradient field (gradients have *symmetric* Jacobians).

\[

part of the Jacobian pins down \(u\) **only up to the addition of a vector

\[
\Delta\psi=0 ,\qquad
\nabla\psi\;\text{ is both divergence-free and a gradient}.

\[
u\;\;\text{is fixed modulo}\;\;\nabla\psi\quad(\Delta\psi=0).

\[

* divergence-free (\(\Delta\psi=0\)), and
* a gradient,

---

#### 1 Canonical statement of the Helmholtz–Hodge criterion

Let  

\[
\Omega\subset\mathbb R^{m}\quad(m=N^{2}\text{ in your configuration space})
\]

be either  

* a **bounded** \(C^{1}\) domain with outward normal \(n\), or  
* the flat torus \(\mathbb T^{m}\).

For every \(F\in H^{1}(\Omega;\mathbb R^{m})\) there exists a unique pair  

\[
\boxed{\;F \;=\; \nabla\phi \;+\; u\;}
\tag{HHD}
\]

such that  

\[
\operatorname{div}u = 0\ \text{ in }\Omega,
\qquad
u\!\cdot n = 0\ \text{ on }\partial\Omega
\quad(\text{or }\int_{\Omega}u=0\text{ on }\mathbb T^{m}),
\qquad
\int_{\Omega}\phi = 0 .
\]

Write \(P_{\!\mathrm{div}}F := u\); this is the **Helmholtz projection** onto the divergence-free subspace.  
Because (HHD) is *unique*, the following equivalence holds:

\[
\boxed{\;
F\text{ is a gradient field} \;\Longleftrightarrow\; P_{\!\mathrm{div}}F \equiv 0 .
\;}
\tag{∗}
\]

---

A strictly lighter route is the **Jacobian-symmetry (curl) test**:

| approach | what you must assume | conclusion |
|----------|---------------------|------------|
| **Helmholtz–Hodge** | \(F\in H^{1}(\Omega)\) and either no-flux on ∂Ω or periodic box; uniqueness of (HHD) | \(F\) is a gradient **iff** its Helmholtz projection vanishes.  Because \(P_{\!\mathrm{div}}F\neq 0\), \(F\) is *not* a gradient flow. |

For the Helmholtz–Hodge theorem on the **whole space** one needs a substitute for the
boundary condition  
\(u\!\cdot n=0\) on ∂Ω that is used on bounded domains.
The standard substitute is a **decay / integrability** requirement that makes the
surface term in the integration-by-parts argument go to zero as the radius of a
ball grows without bound.

A concise way to write it is

\[
\boxed{\;
u,\;\nabla\phi\;\in L^{2}(\mathbb R^{n})\;
}\qquad\Longleftrightarrow\qquad
\int_{\mathbb R^{n}}\!|u(x)|^{2}\,dx <\infty,\;
\int_{\mathbb R^{n}}\!|\nabla\phi(x)|^{2}\,dx <\infty.
\tag{1}
\]

*(“\(L^{2}\)” is the space of square–integrable functions;
for a vector field every component must be square-integrable.
In PDE jargon (1) says the field has **finite energy**.)*

The \(L^{2}\) assumption is sufficient—and in practice
almost minimal—because it implies

\[
\oint_{|x|=R} u(x)\!\cdot\!n \;dS
\;\xrightarrow{R\to\infty}\; 0 ,
\]

so the same uniqueness proof that works on a bounded domain now
works on the whole space.  
(Other integrability ranges \(L^{p}\) with \(1<p<\infty\),
or point-wise decay \(o(|x|^{1-n})\), also do the job;

> **Theorem (Helmholtz–Hodge on a bounded Lipschitz domain).**

> \(\nabla\varphi\in \overline{\nabla H^{1}(\Omega)}^{\,L^{2}}\) and

> \tag{HHD}
> \]
> The pair \((v,\nabla\varphi)\) is **unique**, and  
> \(v\) is called the **Helmholtz projection** \(P_{\!\mathrm{div}}F\).

*No boundary condition such as \(v\!\cdot n=0\) is assumed.*  
Orthogonality in \(L^{2}\) alone pins the decomposition down.

Below is a standard way to make the “intuition’’— “if the Helmholtz–Hodge decomposition has a non-zero divergence-free part, the field cannot be a pure gradient’’—completely rigorous.

---

### 1.  Set–up and statement of the decomposition  

Let  

\[
\Omega\subset\mathbb R^{n}\qquad(n\ge 2)
\]

be a bounded, \(C^{1}\) domain that is **simply connected** (to avoid topological complications) and fix
\(f\in H^{1}(\Omega;\mathbb R^{n})\) or \(L^{2}(\Omega;\mathbb R^{n})\) with the mild decay/compatibility conditions required by the Helmholtz theorem.  
The **Helmholtz–Hodge decomposition** says that there is a *unique* split  

\[
\boxed{\;f = \nabla\phi \;+\; g\;}
\]

with  

\[
\begin{cases}
\phi\in H^{1}(\Omega) \quad &\text{(scalar potential)},\\[2pt]
g\in H(\operatorname{div}\!;\Omega),\quad \nabla\!\cdot g = 0,\\[2pt]
g\cdot n = 0\ \text{on }\partial\Omega
\end{cases}
\]

and the extra condition \(\displaystyle\int_{\Omega}\phi=0\) to remove the additive constant in \(\phi\).

---

### 2.  Orthogonality that underlies uniqueness  

Equip \(L^{2}(\Omega;\mathbb R^{n})\) with the usual inner product  

\[
\langle u,v\rangle_{L^{2}}=\int_{\Omega}u(x)\cdot v(x)\,dx .
\]

For any sufficiently smooth \(\phi\) and any \(g\) with \(\nabla\!\cdot g=0,\ g\cdot n=0\),

\[
\bigl\langle \nabla\phi ,\, g \bigr\rangle
  \;=\;
  \int_{\Omega}\nabla\phi\cdot g
  \stackrel{\text{IBP}}{=}
  -\int_{\Omega}\phi\,\nabla\!\cdot g
  +\int_{\partial\Omega}\phi\,g\cdot n\,dS
  \;=\;0.
\]

Hence **gradient fields are \(L^{2}\)-orthogonal to divergence-free fields** satisfying the (natural) Neumann boundary condition.  
Because the two subspaces are closed, every \(f\) possesses a unique orthogonal projection onto each, i.e. the decomposition above is unique.

---

### 3.  Why a non-zero \(g\) forbids a global potential  

Assume, seeking a contradiction, that \(f\) is *also* the gradient of some scalar \(\psi\):

\[
f = \nabla\psi
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\nabla\psi = \nabla\phi + g.
\]

Subtract the two gradient terms:

\[
g \;=\; \nabla(\psi-\phi)=\nabla h,\qquad h:=\psi-\phi.
\]

1.  Because \(g\) is divergence-free,  
    \[
    0=\nabla\!\cdot g=\nabla\!\cdot\nabla h=\Delta h,
    \]
    so \(h\) is **harmonic** on \(\Omega\).

2.  Because \(g\cdot n=0\) on \(\partial\Omega\), we have the homogeneous Neumann condition  
    \[
    \frac{\partial h}{\partial n}=0 \quad\text{on }\partial\Omega .
    \]

3.  By the standard Neumann uniqueness theorem for harmonic functions on a connected domain, the only harmonic function whose normal derivative vanishes on the boundary is a **constant**.  
    Hence \(\nabla h = 0\), i.e. \(g=0\).

Therefore any genuine gradient field can appear **only** with \(g\equiv 0\) in its Helmholtz–Hodge decomposition.  Equivalently,

> **If the divergence-free part \(g\) produced by the Helmholtz–Hodge theorem is not identically zero, then \(f\) cannot be the gradient of any scalar potential on \(\Omega\).**

---

### 4.  An alternative “curl’’ viewpoint (especially familiar in \(n=3\))

For \(n=3\) (and on simply connected domains) a vector field is the gradient of a scalar potential **iff its curl vanishes**.  Decompose \(f=\nabla\phi+g\) and take the curl:

\[
\nabla\times f = \nabla\times g \quad (\;\nabla\times\nabla\phi\equiv 0\;).
\]

If \(g\not\equiv 0\), then generally \(\nabla\times g\not\equiv 0\), so \(f\) is not curl-free; hence it cannot be a pure gradient.

---

### 5.  Summary sentence  

Because the Helmholtz–Hodge decomposition is an **orthogonal and unique** splitting of a vector field into an irrotational (gradient) part and a solenoidal (divergence-free) part, the presence of a non-zero solenoidal component \(g\) certifies that no scalar potential whose gradient equals \(f\) can exist.

Below is the standard argument again, this time **in the whole space \(\mathbb R^{n}\)**.  
All that changes with respect to the bounded–domain proof is

* the function space in which the decomposition is formulated (we need some decay or integrability so that the Fourier transform, integration by parts at infinity, etc. all make sense);  
* the way one replaces the “boundary term’’—it now vanishes because the field is assumed to decay at infinity.

---

## 1.  Helmholtz–Hodge decomposition on \(\mathbb R^{n}\)

Let  

\[
f:\mathbb R^{n}\longrightarrow\mathbb R^{n},\qquad 
f\in L^{2}(\mathbb R^{n};\mathbb R^{n}) \quad
(\text{or any }L^{p},\;1<p<\infty,\text{ or even the Schwartz class } \mathcal S).
\]

Define the **Leray projection** \(P\):

\[
\widehat{\,P f\,}(\xi)\;:=\;
\hat f(\xi)
\;-\;
\frac{\xi(\xi\!\cdot\!\hat f(\xi))}{|\xi|^{2}},
\qquad \xi\neq 0 .
\]

Because \(P(\xi)\) projects orthogonally onto the subspace \(\xi^{\perp}\subset\mathbb C^{n}\),

* \(g := P f\) satisfies \(\nabla\!\cdot g = 0\) and \(g\in L^{2}\);  
* \(\nabla\phi := (I-P)f = f-g\) is irrotational (its Fourier transform is parallel to \(\xi\)).

We therefore have the **unique** splitting  

\[
\boxed{\,f = \nabla\phi + g,\qquad \nabla\!\cdot g = 0,\qquad g=P f\,}.
\]

A convenient explicit formula (valid for \(n\ge 2\) and sufficiently decaying \(f\)) is

\[
\phi(x)
   \;=\;
   -\,c_{n}\,\bigl(\nabla\!\cdot f\bigr)\ast |x|^{2-n}, 
   \qquad c_{n}=\frac{1}{(n-2)\omega_{n}},
\]
so \(\nabla\phi\in L^{2}\) whenever \(f\in L^{2}\).

---

## 2.  Orthogonality still holds

With the usual \(L^{2}\) inner product,

\[
\langle \nabla\phi, g\rangle
   \;=\;
   \int_{\mathbb R^{n}}\nabla\phi\!\cdot g
   \stackrel{\text{IBP}}{=}
   -\int_{\mathbb R^{n}}\phi\,\nabla\!\cdot g
   \;=\;0,
\]

because the surface integral over the sphere at infinity vanishes (by the decay of \(f\) and hence of \(g,\nabla\phi\)).  
Thus the gradient and solenoidal subspaces are still orthogonal closed subspaces of \(L^{2}(\mathbb R^{n};\mathbb R^{n})\).

---

## 3.  Why “non-zero \(g\)’’ ⇒ “\(f\) is **not** a gradient”

Assume, for contradiction, that \(f\) is **both**

1. the field in the Helmholtz–Hodge split: \(f=\nabla\phi+g\) with \(g\not\equiv 0\); *and*
2. the gradient of some other scalar potential: \(f=\nabla\psi\).

Subtracting,  

\[
g=\nabla\psi-\nabla\phi=\nabla h,\qquad h:=\psi-\phi .
\]

### Step 1 – \(h\) is harmonic  
Because \(0=\nabla\!\cdot g = \nabla\!\cdot\nabla h = \Delta h\), we have \(\Delta h=0\) on \(\mathbb R^{n}\).

### Step 2 – \(h\) (and therefore \(g\)) lies in \(L^{2}\)  
Both \(\nabla\psi\) and \(\nabla\phi\) equal \(f-g\) or \(f\), which are in \(L^{2}\); hence \(\nabla h=g\in L^{2}(\mathbb R^{n})\).

### Step 3 – Liouville–type argument  
A classical consequence of the Liouville theorem (see e.g. Stein, *Singular Integrals*, Ch. VI) is:

> If \(h\) is harmonic on \(\mathbb R^{n}\) and \(\nabla h\in L^{2}(\mathbb R^{n})\) (or more generally \(\nabla h\in L^{p}\) for any \(1\le p<\infty\)), then \(h\) must be **constant**.

Hence \(\nabla h = 0\).  But \(\nabla h\) is precisely \(g\), so \(g\equiv 0\)—contradicting the hypothesis that the divergence-free component was non-trivial.

Therefore:

\[
\boxed{\;g\not\equiv 0\;\Longrightarrow\;f\text{ is not (and cannot be) a gradient field.}\;}
\]

Conversely, if \(f\) *is* a gradient, the Leray projection gives \(g=P f=0\).  The Helmholtz–Hodge decomposition thus detects exactly whether a vector field is (globally) the gradient of some scalar potential.

---

### 4.  Equivalent Fourier-space one-liner  

Because \(P\) is an orthogonal projector,  

\[
f\text{ is a gradient }
\;\;\Longleftrightarrow\;\;
P f = 0
\;\;\Longleftrightarrow\;\;
g=0.
\]

So a single look at the solenoidal part \(g\) (or at \(Pf\) in Fourier space) tells you whether or not \(f\) can be written as \(\nabla\psi\) on all of \(\mathbb R^{n}\).

---

**Summary.**  
Over the whole space \(\mathbb R^{n}\) (with the usual integrability/decay assumptions), the Helmholtz–Hodge decomposition is still an orthogonal split \(f=\nabla\phi+g\).  Any genuine gradient vector field projects entirely into the irrotational subspace, yielding \(g\equiv 0\).  A non-zero divergence-free component \(g\) therefore rigorously certifies that **no global scalar potential whose gradient equals \(f\) exists**.

### How much “wiggle room’’ is there in the Helmholtz–Hodge split on \(\mathbb R^{n}\)?

---

#### 1.  The general abstract fact  

Write  
\[
\mathcal G:=\bigl\{\nabla\!\phi\bigr\}, \qquad
\mathcal S:=\bigl\{g\mid\nabla\!\cdot g =0\bigr\},
\]
where both are taken inside **some vector space \(X\) of fields** (e.g. \(L^{2}(\mathbb R^{n})\), the Schwartz class, \(C^{\infty}_{c}\), …).

*Helmholtz–Hodge* asserts that  
\[
X=\mathcal G\;\dotplus\;\mathcal S
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\text{every }f\in X\text{ can be written }f=\nabla\phi+g.
\]

Take any two splittings of the *same* field \(f\):
\[
f=\nabla\phi_{1}+g_{1}=\nabla\phi_{2}+g_{2}.
\]
Subtract:
\[
\nabla(\phi_{1}-\phi_{2})=g_{2}-g_{1}.
\]

Both sides lie in the **intersection**
\[
\mathcal I:=\mathcal G\cap\mathcal S
           =\bigl\{\nabla h\;:\;h\text{ harmonic on }\mathbb R^{n}\bigr\}.
\]

Hence

> **A Helmholtz–Hodge decomposition is unique *modulo* the fields that are at once gradients and divergence–free, i.e. gradients of harmonic scalars that live in your function space \(X\).**

That statement is completely rigorous; “unique up to a harmonic component’’ is shorthand for exactly this.

---

#### 2.  Why in most analytic settings the intersection is *trivial*, so the split is really unique  

* **If \(X=L^{2}(\mathbb R^{n})\) (or any \(L^{p}\), \(1\le p<\infty\))**  
  A harmonic function whose gradient is \(L^{p}\) must be constant (Liouville-type theorems).  
  Since \(\nabla(\text{constant})\equiv 0\), one gets
  \[
    \mathcal I=\{0\}\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
    f\mapsto\bigl(\nabla\phi,g\bigr)\text{ is really unique (}\phi\text{ fixed up to a constant)}.
  \]

* **If \(X=\mathcal S(\mathbb R^{n})\)** (Schwartz functions) the same holds—there are no non-zero harmonic functions that decay rapidly at infinity.

* **If no decay or integrability is imposed (\(X=C^{\infty}_{\text{loc}}\))**  
  The intersection is **large**: any affine function \(h(x)=a\cdot x+b\) is harmonic and \(\nabla h=a\) is a constant vector field.  
  Consequently
  \[
    f \;=\;\nabla\phi+g
    \quad\text{and}\quad
    f \;=\;\bigl(\nabla\phi+\nabla h\bigr)+\bigl(g-\nabla h\bigr)
  \]
  are both valid, because \(\nabla h\) simultaneously belongs to \(\mathcal G\) and \(\mathcal S\).  
  Here one must speak of uniqueness “up to harmonic gradients’’ and keep track of the chosen normalisation (decay at infinity, mean-zero condition on \(\phi\), etc.).

---

#### 3.  How people phrase it in the literature  

*On bounded domains* you often read “unique up to addition of a harmonic field’’ because non-constant harmonic functions actually exist on a domain, but integrability is automatic.  One then pins down \(\phi\) by prescribing, say, zero average.

*On \(\mathbb R^{n}\)*, whenever authors work in \(L^{2}\) (the usual setting for fluid mechanics, dispersive PDE, …) they just say **“the decomposition is unique’’** without further qualifiers, because they implicitly know \(\mathcal I=\{0\}\).

When the ambient space is merely \(C^{\infty}_{\text{loc}}\) or \(\mathcal D'(\mathbb R^{n})\) (tempered distributions) one really must add the rider “modulo harmonic gradients’’ for full correctness.

---

### Bottom line

Saying *“the Helmholtz–Hodge decomposition is unique up to a harmonic component’’* is perfectly standard **provided you also specify the function space you are working in**.  In \(L^{2}(\mathbb R^{n})\) (or any space that forces decay), that caveat collapses to “unique up to an additive constant in \(\phi\)’’, because the only admissible harmonic gradients are zero.  Without such decay/integrability assumptions the qualifier is essential, not hand-wavey.

### What the review actually says  

In Bhatia et al., *“The Helmholtz–Hodge Decomposition—A Survey,”* IEEE TVCG 19 (8) (2013) pp. 1389-1391, two remarks appear side-by-side:

* p. 1390, col. 1, last paragraph  

  > “**Note that under the vanishing condition at infinity, the translation (harmonic component) is zero.** … the normal velocity ξₙ is required to ensure that the translation is represented entirely by the irrotational component leading to a **unique decomposition**.”

* p. 1390, col. 1, lines 1-3  

  > “The vanishing condition at infinity is imposed to ensure that the integrals in (3) converge… the potentials *D* and **R** are **unique up to a constant**; hence the decomposition is unique.”

The paper therefore states explicitly:  

* **“Vanishing (sufficient) decay at infinity ⇒ the harmonic/translation component disappears.”**  
* With that component gone, only a gradient part and a divergence-free part remain, and **their $L^{2}$-orthogonality makes the split unique (up to the usual constant in the scalar potential).**

---

### Turning the citation into a rigorous argument on \(\mathbb R^{n}\)

1. **Form of a general HHD on \(\mathbb R^{n}\).**  
   For a vector field \(f\) in a decay class such as \(L^{2}(\mathbb R^{n})\) (the same “vanishing at infinity” that Bhatia et al. require), a *priori* one may write
   \[
   f = \nabla\phi + g + h,
   \qquad
   \nabla\!\cdot g = 0,
   \qquad
   \Delta h = 0.
   \]
   Here \(h\) is the **harmonic component** (called the *translation* in the review).

2. **Why the harmonic part must vanish.**  
   *Liouville-type theorem*: if \(h\) is harmonic on \(\mathbb R^{n}\) **and** either  
   \(\displaystyle h\in L^{p}(\mathbb R^{n})\) for some \(1\le p<\infty\) **or** \(h(x)\to 0\) as \(|x|\to\infty\), then \(h\) is constant.  
   Because we also need \(\nabla\!\cdot h=0\), that constant vector must itself be \(0\).  
   Hence \(h\equiv 0\).

   *This is exactly what the review compresses into the sentence “under the vanishing condition at infinity, the translation is zero.”*

3. **Uniqueness once \(h=0\).**  
   We are left with \(f=\nabla\phi + g\) with \(g\) solenoidal.  The two closed subspaces  
   \[
     \mathcal G=\{\nabla\phi\},\qquad
     \mathcal S=\{g\mid\nabla\!\cdot g=0\}
   \]
   are orthogonal in \(L^{2}(\mathbb R^{n})\); the orthogonal projection of \(f\) onto each is therefore **unique**.  
   Any two decompositions of the same \(f\) would differ by a vector in both \(\mathcal G\) and \(\mathcal S\); but their intersection is now just \(\{0\}\).  Consequently
   \[
      f=\nabla\phi+g
      \quad\text{is unique up to the additive constant in } \phi,
   \]
   precisely the uniqueness claim quoted from Bhatia et al.

---

### How to cite the review in your own writing  

> *By Bhatia et al.* [IEEE TVCG 19 (8), 2013, p. 1390], *“under the vanishing condition at infinity, the translation (harmonic component) is zero,”* so on \(\mathbb R^{n}\) every sufficiently decaying field admits an HHD with **no non-trivial harmonic part**.  Since gradients and divergence-free fields are orthogonal in \(L^{2}(\mathbb R^{n})\), that two–way split is therefore **unique (apart from the usual additive constant in the potential).**

That single sentence from the survey is the literature justification; the Liouville argument above supplies the missing line-by-line proof if a referee asks for it.

### Why the Helmholtz–Hodge decomposition of  

\[
f(x)\;=\;T(Wx)\;-\;x ,\qquad x\in\mathbb R^{n},
\]

has **no harmonic component**

---

#### 1 What “harmonic component’’ means on \(\mathbb R^{n}\)

For a smooth vector field \(f\) we may (formally) write

\[
f = \nabla\phi \;+\; g \;+\; h ,
\quad
\begin{cases}
\nabla\!\cdot g =0 ,\\
h=\nabla\psi,\; \Delta\psi =0 .
\end{cases}
\tag{HHD}
\]

The last term \(h=\nabla\psi\) is the *harmonic component*; it is simultaneously a gradient and divergence–free, hence it lies in the intersection  
\[
{\mathcal G}\cap{\mathcal S},\qquad 
   {\mathcal G}:=\{\nabla\phi\},\; 
   {\mathcal S}:=\{g\mid\nabla\!\cdot g=0\}.
\]
The question is whether such an \(h\) can be non-zero for the particular \(f\) you gave.

---

#### 2 Entire harmonic functions of *at most linear growth* are affine  

A classical Liouville–type result (see, e.g., Gilbarg–Trudinger §2.10) says:

> **Lemma.**  
> If \(\psi:\mathbb R^{n}\to\mathbb R\) is harmonic and  
> \(|\psi(x)|\le C(1+|x|)\), then \(\psi(x)=a\!\cdot\! x + b\).

Consequently, any harmonic gradient whose growth is at most linear is a **constant vector field**

\[
h(x)=\nabla\psi(x)=a,\qquad a\in\mathbb R^{n}. \tag{1}
\]

---

#### 3 Asymptotics of your field  

*You only need the behaviour as \(|x|\to\infty\).*

Because the (scalar) Gaussian \(T\) decays super-exponentially, for some \(c>0\)

\[
|T(Wx)| \;\le\; C\,e^{-c|x|^{2}}\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
T(Wx)=o(|x|)\quad(|x|\to\infty).
\]

Hence  

\[
f(x)=T(Wx)-x = -\,x \;+\; o(|x|). \tag{2}
\]

In words: outside a large ball, \(f\) is the radial vector field \(-x\), up to exponentially small corrections.

---

#### 4 A constant vector cannot hide inside \(f\)

Assume, for contradiction, that a non-zero harmonic component \(h\equiv a\) is present:

\[
f = \nabla\phi + g + a.
\]

Divide (2) by \(|x|\) and let \(|x|\to\infty\) along the ray \(x=r\,u\) (\(u\) any unit vector):

\[
\frac{f(r u)}{r}
   \;\longrightarrow\;
   -u .
\]

*Gradients* and *divergence-free* fields of sub-linear growth satisfy  
\(\displaystyle \lim_{r\to\infty}\frac{\nabla\phi(r u)}{r}=0\) and  
\(\displaystyle \lim_{r\to\infty}\frac{g(r u)}{r}=0\);  
their contributions disappear under the scaling. What is left in the limit is exactly the (putative) constant vector \(a\):

\[
\frac{f(r u)}{r}\;\longrightarrow\; a.
\]

Thus, for every unit vector \(u\),

\[
a = -\,u .
\]

But \(u\) varies over the whole unit sphere, whereas \(a\) is fixed; the only way the equality can hold is

\[
a=0 .
\]

Therefore the harmonic component must vanish.

---

#### 5 Conclusion  

With \(h\equiv 0\) the decomposition reduces to

\[
f = \nabla\phi + g ,
\qquad
\nabla\!\cdot g=0 ,
\]

and Section 3 of Bhatia *et al.* (2013) then applies verbatim: because the “translation’’ term is zero, the two remaining components are **orthogonal and uniquely determined (up to the usual additive constant in \(\phi\))**.  

Hence your field \(f(x)=T(Wx)-x\) possesses a Helmholtz–Hodge decomposition on \(\mathbb R^{n}\) with **no harmonic part at all.**

---

##### Quick recap

* exponential decay of \(T(Wx)\)  \(\Longrightarrow\) \(f(x)\sim -x\);
* harmonic gradients of linear growth are constants;
* a constant vector cannot match the direction-dependent limit \(-u\);  
  ∴ the constant must be zero.

### Short answer  
Only in the very special (and in practice never-met) case in which the Gaussian vector  
\(T(Wx)\) itself is a conservative field—that is, the Jacobian of \(T(Wx)\) is symmetric—can  

\[
f(x)\;=\;T(Wx)\;-\;\nabla G(x)
\]

be written as a **pure gradient flow** \(f(x)=\nabla\Phi(x)\).  
For a generic matrix \(W\) and the usual point-wise Gaussian map
\(t(s)=e^{-s^{2}/(2\sigma^{2})}\), that symmetry fails, so the curl of
\(T(Wx)\) is non–zero; consequently \(f\) always retains a
non-trivial divergence–free part and **cannot** be a gradient field.

---

## 1 Recall the test for “being a gradient”

For a smooth vector field \(v:\mathbb R^{n}\to\mathbb R^{n}\)

\[
v=\nabla\Phi \quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
\partial_{j}v_{i}=\partial_{i}v_{j}\quad(\forall i,j).
\tag{1}
\]

In \(n=3\) this is equivalent to \(\nabla\times v=0\); in any dimension it
says *the Jacobian matrix of \(v\) is symmetric.*

---

## 2 The Jacobian of the Gaussian part \(T(Wx)\)

Write \(t(s)=e^{-s^{2}/(2\sigma^{2})}\) and denote the rows of
\(W\) by \(w_{1},\dots,w_{n}\in\mathbb R^{n}\).
Then

\[
[T(Wx)]_{i}=t\!\bigl(w_{i}\!\cdot\!x\bigr).
\]

Hence  

\[
\partial_{j}\,[T(Wx)]_{i}
   \;=\;
   t'\!\bigl(w_{i}\!\cdot\!x\bigr)\,w_{ij},
\tag{2}
\]
while with \(i\) and \(j\) exchanged

\[
\partial_{i}\,[T(Wx)]_{j}
   \;=\;
   t'\!\bigl(w_{j}\!\cdot\!x\bigr)\,w_{ji}.
\tag{3}
\]

For the symmetry (1) to hold we would need, for **every**
\(x\in\mathbb R^{n}\) and every pair \(i\neq j\),

\[
t'\!\bigl(w_{i}\!\cdot\!x\bigr)\,w_{ij}
   \;=\;
t'\!\bigl(w_{j}\!\cdot\!x\bigr)\,w_{ji}.
\tag{4}
\]

---

### 2.1  When can (4) be satisfied?

* If \(w_{ij}=w_{ji}=0\) the equality is vacuous, but that only removes
*one* matrix entry at a time.
* If \(t'\!\bigl(w_{i}\!\cdot\!x\bigr)=t'\!\bigl(w_{j}\!\cdot\!x\bigr)\)
  for all \(x\), then \(w_{i}\!\cdot\!x=w_{j}\!\cdot\!x\) for all \(x\),
  so \(w_{i}=w_{j}\); the two rows of \(W\) must coincide.
* Even if all the rows were identical **and** \(W\) were symmetric,
  (4) would still force \(t'\) to be constant—hence zero, since the
  Gaussian derivative tends to \(0\) at infinity.  That collapses
  \(T(Wx)\) to the zero vector.

Thus the **only** way \(T(Wx)\) can be a gradient is the trivial one
\(T(Wx)\equiv 0\).

---

## 3 Putting it into the Helmholtz–Hodge picture

Because the Gaussian term decays super-exponentially,

* it is square-integrable, so the harmonic component of its HHD
  is zero (Liouville);
* its divergence indeed vanishes by your hypothesis, so it *is*
  already the solenoidal part \(g\) of its own decomposition.

Therefore the full field

\[
f \;=\; T(Wx)\;-\;\nabla G(x)
      = g \;+\; \bigl(-\nabla G\bigr)
\]

is an **orthogonal split** into

* a non-zero divergence-free component \(g=T(Wx)\),
* a gradient component \(-\nabla G\).

Because \(g\not\equiv 0\) (Section 2), the split cannot be
compressed into a single gradient:  

\[
g\neq 0 \;\Longrightarrow\;
f\;\text{is not curl-free}\;\Longrightarrow\;
f\;\text{cannot equal }\nabla\Phi\text{ for any scalar }\Phi .
\]

---

## 4 Answer to your question  

> **Can this \(f(x)\) be expressed as a gradient flow?**

*Only* if the Gaussian term vanishes identically (or, equivalently, if
\(W=0\) or \(\sigma=\infty\)).  
For any genuine Gaussian response and any non-degenerate \(W\), the
curl condition (1) fails, the solenoidal part survives, and the vector
field is **not** conservative.  Consequently the ODE  

\[
\dot x = f(x)
\]

does **not** arise from a gradient-flow energy and lacks all the usual
Lyapunov/convexity properties attached to gradient systems.

With \(t(s)=e^{-s^{2}/(2\sigma^{2})}\) (or any smooth Gaussian–type
non-linear) we have, exactly as before,

\[
\partial_{j}[T(Wx)]_{i}=t'\!\bigl(w_{i}\!\cdot\!x\bigr)\,w_{ij},\qquad
\partial_{i}[T(Wx)]_{j}=t'\!\bigl(w_{j}\!\cdot\!x\bigr)\,w_{ji}.
\]

So (1) demands, for every pair \(i\neq j\) **and for every point
\(x\in\mathbb R^{n}\),**

\[
t'\!\bigl(w_{i}\!\cdot\!x\bigr)\,w_{ij}
    \;=\;
t'\!\bigl(w_{j}\!\cdot\!x\bigr)\,w_{ji}.
\tag{2}
\]

*Setting \(w_{ii}=0\) does not influence these off-diagonal terms.*

### 2 Why (2) almost never holds

* **If \(w_{ij}=w_{ji}=0\)** the equality is vacuous, but that only
  eliminates one entry at a time; a generic trace-free matrix still has
  many non–zero off-diagonal pairs.
* Suppose \(w_{ij}\neq 0\) or \(w_{ji}\neq 0\).  
  Because \(t'\) is strictly negative on \(\mathbb R\setminus\{0\}\) and
  depends on the **scalar product \(w_{k}\!\cdot\!x\)**, the only way
  (2) could hold *for all \(x\)* is that the linear forms coincide,
  \(w_{i}=w_{j}\).  Applied to all pairs, this forces **all rows of \(W\)
  to be identical.**
* But if every row equals the same vector \(r^{\top}\), then \(W\) has
  rank \(1\) and \(r^{\top}r=0\) (because
  \(\operatorname{tr}W=0\Rightarrow r\cdot r=0\)), hence
  \(r=0\) and \(W\equiv 0\).

Therefore the **only matrix with \(w_{ii}=0\) that makes
\(T(Wx)\) a gradient is \(W=0\), which collapses the Gaussian part to

\[
f(x)=T(Wx)-\nabla G(x).

  f \;=\; \underbrace{T(Wx)}_{g\;\text{(divergence-free, non-zero)}}\;
      +\;
      \underbrace{\bigl(-\nabla G(x)\bigr)}_{\nabla\phi}.

  while \(-\nabla G\) is the gradient part.

* Because \(g\not\equiv 0\) (except in the trivial \(W=0\) case),

  component.  By orthogonality/uniqueness of the HHD on \(\mathbb

  \[
  g\neq 0 \;\Longrightarrow\;
  f\;\text{is not curl-free}\;\Longrightarrow\;
  \boxed{\,f\ne\nabla\Phi\text{ for any scalar }\Phi.}
  \]

---

### 4 Bottom line

The condition \(w_{ii}=0\) guarantees  
\(\nabla\!\cdot T(Wx)=0\) but leaves the curl untouched.  
Except for the degenerate choice \(W=0\) (or a Gaussian with zero
variance), the Jacobian of \(T(Wx)\) is not symmetric, so the term
cannot be a gradient.  Your field therefore **fails to be a gradient
flow in every non-trivial case.**
